name: Stevie Wonder
description:
'''Stevland Hardaway Morris''' ({{IPAc-en|ˈ|s|t|iː|v|l|ə|n|d}} {{respell|STEEV|lənd}}; {{né|'''Judkins'''}}; born May 13, 1950), known professionally as '''Stevie Wonder''', is an American singer-songwriter, musician, and record producer. He is widely regarded as one of the most influential musicians of the 20th century. Wonder is credited as a pioneer and influence by musicians across a range of genres that include [[Contemporary R&B|R&B]], [[Pop music|pop]], [[Soul music|soul]], [[Gospel music|gospel]], [[funk]], and [[jazz]]. A virtual [[one-man band]], Wonder's use of [[synthesizer]]s and other [[electronic musical instrument]]s during the 1970s reshaped the conventions of [[contemporary R&B]]. He also helped drive such genres into the [[album era]], crafting his [[LP record|LPs]] as cohesive and consistent, in addition to socially conscious statements with complex compositions. Blind since shortly after his birth, Wonder was a [[child prodigy]] who signed with [[Motown]]'s [[Tamla]] label at the age of 11, where he was given the professional name '''Little Stevie Wonder'''.

Wonder's single "[[Fingertips]]" was a No. 1 hit on the [[Billboard Hot 100|''Billboard'' Hot 100]] in 1963, when he was 13, making him the [[List of Billboard Hot 100 chart achievements and milestones#Age records|youngest solo artist ever]] to top the chart. Wonder's critical success was at its peak in the 1970s. His "classic period" began in 1972 with the releases of ''[[Music of My Mind]]'' and ''[[Talking Book]]'', the latter featuring "[[Superstition (song)|Superstition]]", which is one of the most distinctive and famous examples of the sound of the [[Clavinet|Hohner Clavinet]] keyboard. His works ''[[Innervisions]]'' (1973), ''[[Fulfillingness' First Finale]]'' (1974) and ''[[Songs in the Key of Life]]'' (1976) all won the [[Grammy Award for Album of the Year]], making him the only artist to have won the award with three consecutive album releases. Wonder began his "commercial period" in the 1980s; he achieved his biggest hits and highest level of fame, had increased album sales, charity participation, high-profile collaborations (including with [[Paul McCartney]] and [[Michael Jackson]]), political impact, and television appearances. Wonder has continued to remain active in music and political causes.

Wonder is one of the [[List of best-selling music artists|best-selling music artists of all time]], with sales of over 100 million records worldwide. He has won 25 [[Grammy Awards]] (the most by a male solo artist) and one [[Academy Awards|Academy Award]] ([[Academy Award for Best Song|Best Original Song]], for the 1984 film ''[[The Woman in Red (1984 film)|The Woman in Red]]''). Wonder has been inducted into the [[Rhythm and Blues Music Hall of Fame]], the [[Rock and Roll Hall of Fame]] and the [[Songwriters Hall of Fame]]. He is also noted for his political activism, including his 1980 campaign to make [[Martin Luther King Jr.]]'s birthday a [[Martin Luther King Jr. Day|federal holiday]] in the United States. In 2009, Wonder was named a [[United Nations Messengers of Peace|United Nations Messenger of Peace]], and in 2014, he was honored with the [[Presidential Medal of Freedom]]. He was conferred [[Ghana]]ian citizenship in 2024.
